<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_device_open:
```c
int metal_device_open(const char *bus_name, const char *dev_name,
		      struct metal_device **device)
{
	struct metal_bus *bus;
	int error;

	if (!bus_name || !strlen(bus_name) ||
	    !dev_name || !strlen(dev_name) ||
	    !device)
		return -EINVAL;

	error = metal_bus_find(bus_name, &bus);
	if (error)
		return error;

	if (!bus->ops.dev_open)
		return -ENODEV;

	error = (*bus->ops.dev_open)(bus, dev_name, device);
	if (error)
		return error;

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
error = metal_bus_find(bus_name, &bus);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The fragment only calls metal_bus_find(bus_name, &bus). Prior checks ensure bus_name is non-NULL and strlen(bus_name) > 0, so there is no immediate use of <string.h> functions in this fragment that would access beyond the object bounds. (Note: the earlier calls to strlen must themselves operate on a null-terminated object; if they were given a non-terminated buffer then those strlen calls — not this fragment — would violate Rule 21.17.)
